challenges.name: Intro to Machine Learning
challenges.description: Ever wonder how programs like Siri and Google assistant are able to talk to us and do things for us, or how YouTube and Instagram suggests images and videos for you based on things that you watched and enjoyed? Maybe even how self driving cars work. These are all done with something called Machine Learning.

challenges.name: Intro Continued...
challenges.description: Machine learning is the idea that computers learn based on data. Data is information, whether it is about images, house prices, medical information, etc. Data is all around us, and it can be used for Machine Learning. Mathematical algorithms are used to make a machine predict things based on that information. Data is fed into the computer and the computer learns from the data and it gets better the more data is fed into the algorithm. Before machine learning, computers were directly programmed to do specific things.

challenges.name: Machine Learning Examples
challenges.description: Let's say we want to program a computer to detect license plates. Before machine learning, we would have to program each part of the license plate. For example, the plate is white, it has six characters and it has curves on 4 corners. As you can see, this can be very inconvenient because there are so many different type of license plates. Instead, we can use an algorithm and give the computer images of license plates so that it can learn what a licence plate looks like.

challenges.name: Types of Machine Learning
challenges.description: There are 3 different types of machine learning. Supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and reinforcement learning. In this lesson, we are going to focus on supervised learning using linear regression which is an algorithm we can then use to predict house prices.
challenges.codeblockarea:
Supervised Learning:

In supervised Learning, both input and output data is provided. Inputs and output data are labelled for classification.

Unsupervised Learning

Unlike supervised learning, unsupervised learning has unlabeled data. That means that the algorithm is presented with uncategorised data that is unlabel and the algorithm needs to come up with patterns found in the data to classify them with each other. Unsupervised learning is can be unpredictable.

Reinforcement Learning

Reinforcement learning has no data. Instead, it is a type of programming that trains algorithms with rewards and punishments. A reinforcement learning algorithm learns by interacting with its environment and it receives awards for good moves and gets penalties for performing a bad move. The algorithm can learn completely by itself.

challenges.name: Intro to Linear Regression
challenges.description: The first algorithm we are going to take a look at is linear regression. Linear regression is a supervised learning algorithm. We can use linear regression to predict prices. Linear regression plots a line through numerical data points, that way you can plot a line through all the data points to get the average. For example, you can create an algorithm that predicts the price of a house and you can plot a line through that data using linear regression. With that average line bringing together the square feet and the price of a house we can input any square feet value and with that line that we the computer created we can get an approximate prediction of the price of the house based on our set of data.
challenges.codeblockarea: Above is an example of linear regression, where a line is plotted through some data. We could do this exact thing to place a line between the average square feet of a house and the price so that when we type a square feet we can get the average for what price it would be.

challenges.name: Set up X and Y data
challenges.description:
We have 2 sets of data to work with: the “x” data and the “y” data. The X data is going to be the information about the house (square feet) and the y plot is going to be the actual answer that we will train our model on (this is commonly referred to as the class). Basically we split our data into two parts: square feet of the house (x) and the cost of the house (y). That way we can train our computer to recognize a pattern between the cost of the house and the square feet of the house. Then, when we want to plot our data and our linear regression we can have the x value of the graph (horizontal axis) the square feet of the house, and then the vertical axis the y value to the cost of the house.

Use the set data function to set the X value to square feet and the Y value to the cost.

We want to set some of the data as training data so the computer can learn from it, and then we want to test some of the data to make sure that our algorithm is good.
Let’s split the testing size to 20% of the data. Set that with the `set testing data` block. Make sure that it is split to 20.
